physdesc.extent: 11 standard document boxes, 1 slim document box for audio materials, and 1 flat box for oversized material

did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.
did.abstract: This collection contains course materials, correspondence, written reviews, speeches and lectures, programs, photographs, and audio materials from Lawrence Bell Laurent, a former Professorial Lecturer at the George Washington Univeristy. The material in this collection dates from 1948-2010, and includes records from Laurent's professional career as a radio and television critic for "The Washington Post" and his academic career teaching at American University and George Washington University . The material in the collection covers how his work influenced both his students and his peers in the field of radio and television broadcasting.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 6 series: American University materials, George Washington University materials, Professional career, Correspondence, Photographs, and Audio materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains course materials, correspondence, written reviews, speeches and lectures, programs, photographs, and audio materials. The material dates from 1948-2010. These are the records of Lawrence Laurent from his professional career as a radio and television critic and from his academic career teaching at American University and George Washington University. The material in the collection covers how his work influenced both his students and his peers in the field of radio and television broadcasting.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lawrence Bell Laurent, a professorial lecturer for GWU, had a long career as a radio and television critic. From 1951-1982, Laurent worked as a writer for the Washington Post. After establishing himself as a respected radio critic, he soon became the first television critic for the Washington Post. During this time, he became very involved in the broadcasting industry and developed close relationships with with fellow critics, writers, directors, and actors. In 1982, Laurent retired from his job at the newspaper and began teaching broadcasting and journalism classes at several universities in the Washington, D.C. area. From 1965 to 1984, he taught several courses at American University. Then from 1984 to 2006, Laurent worked at the George Washington University as a Professorial Lecturer in both Journalism and Media and Public Affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include lecture notes, quizzes, exams, handouts, and other resources. The materials range in date from 1965 to 1984. These materials represent Laurent's time as a professor for American University, teaching courses including: Radio-Television Programming, Development of Broadcasting-Film, and Television Programming. The series is arranged in chronological order. Subjects include: television broadcasting, film analysis, TV news coverage and riots, TV drama, soap opera, political broadcasting, and mass communication. The series also includes the award Laurent received in 1978 from American University for Outstanding Teaching.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include lecture notes, quizzes, exams, assignments, handouts, guest lectures, and other resources. The materials range in date from 1984 to 2010. These materials represent Laurent's time as a professor for George Washington University, teaching courses such as Critical Writing and Reviewing. The series is arranged in chronological order. Subjects include: critics and criticism, sitcom history, politics and TV, internet, headlines, poetry, and situational press ethics.

physdesc.extent: Series is split between 3 standard document boxes and 1 flat box for oversize materials

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 3 subseries (1. Written Works by, about, or Reviewed by Laurent, 2. Public Lectures and Speeches, and 3. Miscellaneous Event Invitations, Conference Materials, and Honors). Arranged chronologically within the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include radio and television reviews, drafts, public lectures and speeches, invitations, conference materials, and other resources and notes. The materials range in date from 1948 to 2008. These materials represent Laurent's professional career as a radio and television critic. The series is arranged into 3 subseries: 1) Written works by, about, or reviewed by Laurent, 2) Public lectures and speeches, and 3) Event invitations, conference materials, notes, and honors. The materials within the subseries are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Written works by, about, or reviewed by Laurent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Items of interest within subseries 1 include articles from: the University of Virginia's 'The Cavalier Daily' (1948-1959), 'TV Guide,' 'Television Quarterly,' 'Radio Television Daily,' 'The Washington Post,' and 'INTV Journal.' There are also drafts of works by Lawrence Laurent, Buddy Ebsen, Erik Barnouw, Manny Lucoff, and Richard Laurent.

did.unittitle: "Leroy Collins and the National Association of Broadcasters: Experiment in the Public Interest" by Manny Lucoff
"Resultados En Las Lenguas Romances De Adjectivos Con Desinencias Derivadas De - tle> 1998 8 6

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Items of interest within subseries 2 include lectures and speeches for: the American University convocation, the Phi Beta Kappa Association monthly meeting, the Washington Film Council, the Institute for Education by Radio-Television, the American Women in Radio and Television, the National Association of Television Program Executives, the Virginia Association of Broadcsters, The Washington Post summer interns, and the National Press Club.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Items of interest within subseries 3 include: invitations and programs for events, miscellaneous notes and resources, Laurent's award from Syracuse University for being a guest lecturer of television (1965), Laurent's notebook from the Airlie Seminar on the Art of Radio, and Laurent's ordination certificate from the Universal Life Church (1997).

did.unittitle: Airlie Seminar on the Art of Radio
National Association of Broadcasters: Legal Guide to FCC Broadcast Rules, Regulations and Policies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include written and typed correspondence to and from Lawrence Laurent. The materials range in date from 1948 to 2010. These materials represent Laurent's personal life and professional career as a radio and television critic. The series is arranged in chronological order. Series includes correspondence with the following individuals: Buddy Ebsen, Betty White, Ed Sullivan, Dick Clark, James Stewart, Jack Webb, Drew Pearson, Gypsy Rose Lee, Spike Jones, Red Skelton, Ezra Stone, Tom Tully, Herb Shriner, Danny Thomas, George Gobel, Barbara Walters, Jack Lord, Shelley Berman, Connie B. Gay, Lois F. Stark, Rod Serling, Dan O'Brien, and Congressman Richard Ray. The series also includes letters from 'The Washington Post,' 'Television Quarterly,' CBS Television, the National Broadcasting Company, Inc., the Democratic National Committee, and various universities.

did.unittitle: Correspondence - Bill Clinton and Democratic National Committee

physdesc.extent: Series is split between 1 standard document box and 1 flat box for oversize materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include photographs of or for Lawrence Laurent. The materials range in date from 1955 to 2003. These materials represent Laurent's personal life and professional career as a radio and television critic. The series is arranged in chronological order. Series includes photographs of Laurent with: Rocky Marciano, Bob Pickett, John Neville, Shelley Berman, Dan O'Brien, Andrew Stevens, Jacky Benny, and George Washington University faculty and students. Series also includes autographed photographs from: George Gobel, Pat Brown, Buddy Ebsen, Jack Lord, Tom Tully, and Danny Thomas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series include: a vinyl recording of Laurent on CBS (1948), 11 audio cassette tapes of lectures on television broadcasting (c. 1977) and a corresponding letter from Dan O'Brien. The materials range in date from 1948 to 2005. These materials represent Laurent's profesional career as a radio-TV critic and a professor. The series is arranged in chronological order, with the exception of the letter which was placed before the corresponding cassette tapes.

did.unittitle: Audio Recording of Larry Laurent on CBS
Letter from Dan O'Brien about Audio Cassette Tapes
